items.name: addressing-law-no-2014-78.md
items.title: Addressing (By-law No. 2014–78) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes rules for naming and numbering private roads and buildings within the city, amending existing regulations. It outlines definitions, procedures for applications, requirements for signage (including blade signs and street name signs), and provisions for public notice and enforcement.  It also addresses the transition from previous by-laws, clarifies responsibilities regarding maintenance, and sets fees for various services. Finally, it establishes a timeline for the implementation of certain aspects of the by-law, including the use of specific fonts and sizes for street name signs.

items.name: administrative-penalty-system-appointment-law-law-no-2025-155.md
items.title: Administrative Penalty System Appointment By-law (By-law No. 2025-155) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law establishing the roles of Screening Officers and Hearing Officers within its administrative monetary penalty system, designed to handle appeals of penalties issued for various infractions, including those detected by camera systems. The by-law outlines the responsibilities, appointment processes, and eligibility criteria for these officers, as well as delegation of authority for establishing appointment policies and terms of service.

items.name: amended-heritage-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-176.md
items.title: Amended Heritage Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-176) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has adopted an Amended Heritage Community Improvement Plan to encourage the restoration and rehabilitation of designated heritage buildings, leveraging a Tax Increment Equivalent Grant (TIEG) to incentivize these projects. This plan, stemming from a 2016 task force and subsequent Council directives, aims to align with the city’s economic development priorities and utilizes a process involving application, review, and grant disbursement, subject to specific eligibility criteria, funding limitations, and ongoing monitoring. The by-law repeals a previous version and establishes the framework for the amended program.

items.name: amended-integrated-orleans-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-173.md
items.title: Amended Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-173) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law adopts the Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan, replacing previous plans and by-laws related to St. Joseph Boulevard and Orléans. It’s based on a 2013 Council decision to develop an Orléans CIP, building upon prior initiatives and aligning with provincial planning policies. The plan aims to stimulate economic growth and revitalization in Orléans through incentives for property redevelopment, job creation, and pedestrian-friendly development, particularly near the new LRT line. It establishes a Development Incentive Grant Program with specific criteria and funding levels for three distinct program elements: the St. Joseph Boulevard Main Street Program, the Employment Creation Incentive Program, and the Pedestrian Friendly Streets Program, all subject to meeting certain property value and active use requirements. The program will operate for 10 years and is subject to annual monitoring.

items.name: amended-montreal-road-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-174.md
items.title: Amended Montreal Road Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-174) | City of Ottawa
items.summary:
This by-law outlines the continuation and amendment of a Community Improvement Plan for the Montreal Road area in Ottawa, aiming to stimulate business investment and urban renewal. It details a Tax Increment Equivalent Grant (TIEG) program offering financial incentives to property owners undertaking redevelopment projects within the designated area. 

Key aspects include:

*   **Background:** The plan builds upon previous initiatives and aligns with city-wide economic development goals.
*   **Program Structure:** A TIEG grant will provide up to 50% of the municipal tax increment resulting from the redevelopment, capped at $5 million.
*   **Eligible Projects:** Focuses on redevelopment of properties, with specific requirements for mixed-use developments and support for cultural and social enterprises.
*   **Area Definition:** The project area is defined by a by-law and includes a unique “main street” commercial segment.
*   **Administration & Requirements:**  A detailed process for application, review, and ongoing monitoring is established, including requirements for permits and compliance.
*   **Funding:** The program is funded through increased property tax revenue generated by the improvements.

The by-law aims to revitalize the Montreal Road area through targeted financial incentives and strategic development.

items.name: animal-care-and-control-law-no-2003-077.md
items.title: Animal Care and Control (By-law No. 2003-077) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines the City’s by-laws regarding animal care and control, specifically addressing regulations for cats, dogs, and other animals. It details registration requirements, limitations on the number of animals permitted per household, rules regarding leash laws and running at large, prohibitions on certain animal types, and procedures for dealing with bites, disturbances, and impoundment. The by-law also includes definitions of key terms and references to schedules containing further details, such as fees and prohibited animal lists. It establishes a framework for responsible pet ownership and addresses potential public safety and nuisance concerns related to animals within the city.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232.md
items.title: Appendix B - Amendment Schedule to the Zoning By-law and Interim Control By-laws (By-law No. 2022-232) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document presents an appendix detailing amendments to the City of Ottawa Zoning By-law. It lists each amending by-law in descending numerical order, providing the date of enactment, status, and links to Council meeting records and reports for further review. Copies of the individual by-laws are available at City Hall and the City Archives. The appendix is regularly updated to reflect changes enacted by Ottawa City Council.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232%2F2010-2007.md
items.title: 2010-2007 | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines a series of by-law amendments and enactments primarily affecting land parcels within a specific jurisdiction. The by-laws address zoning, exceptions, and minor corrections, often in conjunction with OMB orders. Many of the by-laws relate to properties along major roadways and streets, including Rideau Street, Innes Road, and various lines and avenues. Several by-laws reference interim control measures and are linked to OMB orders issued between 2008 and 2010.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232%2F2014-2011.md
items.title: 2014-2011 | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines various amendments and removals of holding symbols to the Zoning By-law, primarily affecting land parcels in Ottawa. These changes relate to residential development, commercial uses, and infrastructure projects, including adjustments to property lines, building heights, and zoning designations. Several OMB orders are referenced, indicating that some of these changes were subject to provincial oversight.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232%2F2018-2015.md
items.title: 2018-2015 | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines amendments to zoning bylaws affecting various properties within the City. It details the specific land parcels impacted, the dates the amendments were enacted, their current status (primarily “In Effect”), and references to OMB orders, repealed bylaws, and amended bylaws.  The document primarily focuses on adjustments to zoning regulations, including those related to coach houses, industrial uses, and interim control areas, and includes several removals of holding symbols.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232%2F2022-2019.md
items.title: 2022-2019 | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines several amendments and removals to zoning bylaws within the City of Ottawa, primarily affecting land parcels located along various roadways and streets. These changes include alterations to zoning designations, the removal of holding symbols, and adjustments to specific property boundaries. The amendments were enacted between December 2018 and January 2019, and some have been subsequently amended or repealed.

items.name: atv-orv-and-snowmobile-law-no-2019-421.md
items.title: ATV, ORV and Snowmobile (By-law No. 2019-421) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the operation of All-Terrain Vehicles (ATVs), Multi-Purpose Off-Highway Utility Vehicles (ORVs), Recreational Off-Highway Vehicles (ORVs), and Motorized Snow Vehicles on designated highways and unopened road allowances within the City. It defines these vehicle types, outlines permitted areas, establishes speed limits and seasonal restrictions, and details procedures for new trail applications and expansions of existing networks. The by-law also addresses shared use of trails, enforcement measures, and prohibits operation outside designated areas.

items.name: auditor-general-law-no-2021-5.md
items.title: Auditor General (By-law No. 2021-5) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s by-law establishes the role and responsibilities of the Auditor General, outlining their duties related to financial audits, investigations, and accountability to City Council and its committees, while also detailing access to information, confidentiality, and operational procedures for the Auditor General’s office. It also repeals a previous by-law regarding the same position.

items.name: bilingualism-law-no-2001-170.md
items.title: Bilingualism (By-law No. 2001-170) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law affirms the City’s bilingual nature, establishes a citizen’s right to communicate and receive services in either English or French as outlined in the 2001 bilingualism policy, ensures employee job security during implementation, and mandates collaborative consultation with relevant groups.

items.name: board-law-no-2010-211.md
items.title: Board Up (By-law No. 2010-211) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s “Board Up By-law” outlines requirements for securing vacant or damaged buildings to prevent unauthorized access, detailing procedures for notification, enforcement, and penalties for non-compliance, including the addition of boarding costs to property taxes and potential fines or prohibition orders for offenders.

items.name: boards-management-business-improvement-areas-law-no-2021-255.md
items.title: Boards of Management for Business Improvement Areas (By-law No. 2021-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes standardized governance for Business Improvement Area (BIAs) within the City of Ottawa. It outlines requirements for Board composition, including director appointments and responsibilities, operational procedures, financial management, and accountability measures. Key elements include a minimum/maximum director size, specific director qualifications, term lengths, meeting procedures, conflict of interest protocols, and a framework for addressing director performance issues. The by-law also details the BIA’s role in managing affairs, securing contracts, and ensuring financial stability, while emphasizing transparency and adherence to relevant legislation and City policies. Finally, it establishes procedures for membership, policy adoption, record keeping, and dissolution of the BIA.

items.name: borrowing-upon-30-year-sinking-fund-debentures-law-no-2017-355.md
items.title: Borrowing upon 30 year sinking fund debentures (By-law No. 2017-355) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law authorizes the City of Ottawa to borrow $102,000,000 through the issuance of 30-year sinking fund debentures to finance a designated capital work. The borrowing is justified by municipal legislation, a green debenture framework, and a recent debt limit assessment. The by-law details the terms of the debentures, including payment schedules, sinking fund provisions, and mechanisms for exchange and substitution. It also outlines procedures for issuing new debentures in case of loss or damage and confirms the City’s authority to manage the debt and investment of proceeds.

items.name: borrowing-upon-additional-sinking-fund-debentures-200000000-law-no-2019-272.md
items.title: Borrowing upon additional sinking fund debentures $200,000,000 (By-law No. 2019-272) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law authorizes the City of Ottawa to borrow an additional $200 million through the issuance of sinking fund debentures to finance various capital works projects, primarily related to the Confederation Line light rail expansion. It outlines the legal basis for the borrowing, references previous authorizations and debentures, establishes a framework for the issuance, and details the terms of the new debentures, including their maturity date, interest rate, and sinking fund provisions. The by-law also confirms the City’s right to issue further sinking fund debentures and establishes procedures for transferring and exchanging existing debentures.

items.name: borrowing-upon-additional-sinking-fund-debentures-225000000-law-no-2021-359.md
items.title: Borrowing upon additional sinking fund debentures $225,000,000 (By-law No. 2021-359) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law authorizes the City of Ottawa to borrow an additional $225,000,000 through the issuance of sinking fund debentures to finance a portion of a capital work, specifically related to the Stage 2 Ottawa Light Rail Transit project. The borrowing is permitted under municipal law and previous by-laws, including a 2020 Green Debenture Framework, and is subject to ongoing financial oversight and approval processes. The issuance utilizes a repurchase agreement to maintain a consistent debt structure and adheres to established debt limits and investment policies.  The by-law details the terms of the debentures, including maturity dates, interest rates, and sinking fund provisions, and outlines procedures for transfers, exchanges, and potential replacements of damaged or lost debentures.

items.name: borrowing-upon-sinking-fund-debentures-200000000-law-no-2022-166.md
items.title: Borrowing upon sinking fund debentures $200,000,000 (By-law No. 2022-166) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa is authorizing the borrowing of $200,000,000 through the issuance of sinking fund debentures to finance the Light Rail Transit Stage 2 project, adhering to a Green Debenture Framework. This borrowing is permitted under municipal law, has been reviewed and approved by the City’s financial officer, and is subject to established debt policies and procedures, including a sinking fund to ensure repayment of the principal. The debentures will be issued with specific terms, including interest rates, payment schedules, and provisions for exchange and replacement, all while complying with relevant regulations and ensuring timely payments.

items.name: borrowing-upon-sinking-fund-debentures-300000000-law-no-2020-110.md
items.title: Borrowing upon sinking fund debentures $300,000,000 (By-law No. 2020-110) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law authorizes the City of Ottawa to borrow $300,000,000 through sinking fund debentures to finance a designated capital work. It outlines the legal basis for the borrowing, including previous approvals and a commitment to environmental sustainability. The by-law details the terms of the debentures, including repayment schedules, sinking fund provisions, and procedures for exchange or replacement. It also establishes delegated authority for issuing the debentures and confirms the City’s commitment to adhering to established financial policies and regulations.

items.name: building-law-no-2014-220.md
items.title: Building (By-law No. 2014-220) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for construction, renovation, and changes of use within the City, aligning with the Ontario Building Code. It defines key terms, outlines required information for permit applications, and details inspection procedures. The by-law also addresses specific requirements for different building types and classifications, including fees associated with various stages of the process, and provides guidelines for fencing and site safety. Finally, it establishes procedures for revisions, cancellations, and refunds related to permits.

items.name: city-manager-law-no-2025-68.md
items.title: City Manager (By-law No. 2025-68) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes the position of City Manager, outlining their responsibilities as the Chief Administrative Officer, accountability to Council, appointment and removal procedures, and the repeal of a previous by-law regarding the same role.

items.name: clothing-donation-box-law-no-2023-425.md
items.title: Clothing Donation Box (By-law No. 2023–425) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the operation of clothing donation boxes within the City, aiming to prevent public nuisances and ensure responsible practices. It establishes permitting requirements, outlines responsibilities for owners and operators, and details conditions for placement on municipal property. The by-law also includes provisions for enforcement, data collection, and a process for appealing decisions regarding permits. It establishes a framework for managing these donation boxes to promote transparency, environmental responsibility, and public safety.

items.name: code-conduct-members-council-law-no-2025-99.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Members of Council (By-law No. 2025-99) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a code of conduct for Ottawa City Council members, outlining their responsibilities regarding integrity, transparency, and adherence to legislation. It details procedures for handling complaints, including an informal process and a formal investigation conducted by the Integrity Commissioner. The code addresses topics such as conflicts of interest, confidential information, conduct at meetings, discrimination, lobbying, use of municipal resources, and expenses. It also sets out potential sanctions for violations and establishes a process for reporting to Council, while acknowledging limitations during election periods.

items.name: code-conduct-members-local-boards-law-no-2018-399.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Members of Local Boards (By-law No. 2018-399) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a code of conduct for members of local boards in Ottawa, outlining their responsibilities regarding integrity, conflicts of interest, confidentiality, and appropriate behavior during meetings. It details definitions, application, and procedures for handling complaints, including an annual disclosure requirement for gifts and benefits, and outlines potential sanctions for violations. The by-law also addresses specific considerations for adjudicative boards, election-related activity, and staff relations, and establishes a process for reporting and addressing breaches of the code.

items.name: code-conduct-public-members-built-heritage-committee-law-no-2025-77.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Public Members of the Built Heritage Committee (By-law No. 2025-77) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a code of conduct for members of the Built Heritage Committee in Ottawa, outlining their responsibilities and obligations to uphold integrity, transparency, and ethical behavior. It details legal frameworks governing their conduct, defines key terms, and sets forth procedures for handling complaints, including those related to conflicts of interest, lobbying, and the use of municipal resources. The by-law also addresses appropriate conduct at committee meetings and emphasizes respect for staff, while prohibiting discriminatory or harassing behavior. Finally, it establishes a process for reporting and addressing violations of the code, with potential sanctions for non-compliance.

items.name: community-benefits-charge-law-law-no-2022-307.md
items.title: Community Benefits Charge By-law (By-law No. 2022-307) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Community Benefits Charge By-law 2022 outlines regulations for fees levied on new development projects to fund city services and infrastructure improvements. It specifies criteria for triggering the charge – primarily projects exceeding five stories and ten residential units – and details exemptions, valuation processes, payment methods (including in-kind contributions), and timelines for permit issuance. The by-law also establishes a review process and clarifies how it interacts with the Planning Act and existing development agreements.

items.name: community-safety-zone-law-no-2019-397.md
items.title: Community Safety Zone (By-law No. 2019-397) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines a by-law designating community safety zones throughout the City of Ottawa, specifying roadways, speed limits, and school locations within those zones, and referencing previously repealed by-laws related to similar designations.

items.name: compliance-reports-law-no-2003-069.md
items.title: Compliance Reports (By-law No. 2003-069) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Compliance Reports By-law No. 2003-069 establishes procedures and fees for requesting various reports from the Development Services Department, including Summary, Zoning, Pool Enclosure, Agreement, and Rooming House Compliance Reports, outlining specific fee structures for different property types and services.

items.name: contribution-rebate-program-law-no-2022-76.md
items.title: Contribution Rebate Program (By-law No. 2022-76) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Contribution Rebate Program By-law outlines the conditions for individuals to receive rebates on contributions made to participating candidates during municipal elections, detailing eligibility requirements, application procedures, candidate responsibilities, and rebate calculations, while also repealing previous versions of the by-law.

items.name: delegation-authority-law-no-2025-69.md
items.title: Delegation of Authority (By-law No. 2025-69) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a framework for the City’s delegation of authority, outlining definitions, responsibilities, and procedures for various departments and officials. It details how the City Manager, General Managers, and other staff can delegate tasks related to legal agreements, property acquisition, financial matters, and service delivery. Key provisions include specific guidelines for handling emergency situations, ensuring compliance with provincial legislation, and managing relationships with external organizations. The by-law also establishes procedures for approving contracts, managing real estate, and addressing legal matters, with reporting requirements to ensure accountability.

items.name: demolition-control-law-no-2012-377.md
items.title: Demolition Control (By-law No. 2012-377) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law establishing an area of demolition control within specified boundaries, replacing a previous by-law, to preserve the integrity of neighborhoods by regulating residential property demolition and ensuring replacement development standards are met.

items.name: deputy-mayors-law-no-2023-11.md
items.title: Deputy Mayors (By-law No. 2023-11) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City Council has enacted a by-law to designate Councillors as Deputy Mayors who can temporarily assume the Mayor’s duties when the Mayor is unavailable, with specific timeframes and procedures outlined in Schedule A, and to repeal the previous by-law regarding this appointment process, effective January 1, 2023.

items.name: discharge-firearms-law-no-2002-344.md
items.title: Discharge of Firearms (By-law No. 2002-344) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the discharge of firearms within the City of Ottawa, outlining prohibited areas (shaded zones, navigable waters, and proximity to certain buildings and public lands), exceptions for specific individuals and activities (peace officers, farmers, gun club members, etc.), and repeals previous municipal firearms regulations.

items.name: e-scooters-law-no-2020-174.md
items.title: E-scooters (By-law No. 2020 - 174) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Electric Kick Scooter By-law regulates the operation and use of electric kick scooters on City property, outlining definitions, operational rules (speed limits, permitted locations, safety requirements like helmets and lights), parking regulations, and penalties for violations. The by-law also details procedures for removal and impounding of scooters, with associated storage fees, and specifies enforcement responsibilities.

items.name: encroachments-city-highways-law-no-2003-446.md
items.title: Encroachments on City Highways (By-law No. 2003-446) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates encroachments onto City highways, defining key terms, outlining exemptions, and establishing procedures for permits, fees, and enforcement. It details specific regulations for various types of encroachments – aerial, surface, and subsurface – including those related to tourist information, waste receptacles, and customer service boxes. The by-law also addresses temporary encroachments and establishes a schedule of fees and penalties for non-compliance, with a focus on maintaining highway safety and accessibility.

items.name: fence-law-no-2003-462.md
items.title: Fence (By-law No. 2003-462) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Fence By-law (consolidated as of May 9, 2018) regulates the construction, height, and maintenance of fences, outlining specific rules for various property types, including residential, non-residential, and agricultural. It establishes maximum fence heights, addresses visibility considerations, defines key terms, and specifies requirements for materials, construction, and upkeep, while also detailing exemptions and repealing previous municipal by-laws.

items.name: film-law-law-no-2020-164.md
items.title: Film By-law (By-law No. 2020-164) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law governs filming events on City and private property in Ottawa, outlining permitting procedures, responsibilities, and requirements for organizers. It establishes definitions for key terms like “applicant,” “permit,” “crew,” and “emergency plan,” and details specific conditions for events requiring City resources, traffic management, or special safety measures. The by-law mandates advance notice, comprehensive applications including traffic and security plans, and adherence to City policies and provincial/federal regulations. It also outlines appeal processes and consequences for non-compliance, emphasizing the City’s authority to ensure public safety and minimize disruption.

items.name: fire-routes-law-no-2003-499.md
items.title: Fire Routes (By-law No. 2003-499) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s “Fire Routes By-law” designates specific roadways and access points as fire routes, outlines requirements for signage and maintenance by property owners, and establishes penalties for obstructing or interfering with these routes, while also repealing previous municipal regulations regarding fire routes.

items.name: fire-routes-law-no-2003-499%2Fschedule-fire-routes.md
items.title: Schedule A – Fire Routes | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document consolidates the City of Ottawa Fire Routes By-law, incorporating numerous amendments from 2003 to 2024. It details the addresses and street names of 157 individual fire routes, providing a comprehensive record of designated fire access points within the city.

items.name: fireworks-law-no-2003-237.md
items.title: Fireworks (By-law No. 2003-237) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This consolidated by-law regulates fireworks within the City of Ottawa, outlining restrictions on sale, discharge, and permits for both consumer and display fireworks. It defines key terms, specifies permitted days for discharge, mandates permit requirements for displays, and details conditions for obtaining and adhering to those permits. Existing by-laws from previous municipalities are repealed, and a reporting mechanism for improper discharges is provided.

items.name: graffiti-management-law-no-2008-01.md
items.title: Graffiti Management (By-law No. 2008-01) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Graffiti Management By-law prohibits the placement and failure to remove graffiti on property, outlining procedures for notice, compliance, and penalties, with specific exemptions for designated areas.

items.name: heat-law-no-2010-210.md
items.title: Heat (By-law No. 2010-210) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Heat By-law establishes minimum temperature requirements (16.67°C/62°F at night and 20°C/68°F during the day) for rental dwellings, mandates landlords to maintain adequate heat, and outlines a process for the Director to issue notices and, if necessary, enter the property to ensure compliance, with potential fines and prohibition orders for violations.

items.name: idling-control-law-no-2024-437.md
items.title: Idling Control (By-law No. 2024-437) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s “Idling Control By-law” regulates vehicle idling, establishing time limits for idling based on temperature, with exceptions for specific vehicles and circumstances, and outlines enforcement procedures and penalties, while also repealing a previous by-law on the same subject and taking effect on January 1, 2025.

items.name: information-and-materials-planning-applications-law-no-2023-297.md
items.title: Information and Materials for Planning Applications (By-law No. 2023-297) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s by-law outlines a comprehensive list of required information and materials beyond standard planning application requirements, encompassing detailed studies and analyses for various development types, and specifies the by-law’s citation, repeal of a previous by-law, and effective date.

items.name: integrated-orleans-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2021-284.md
items.title: Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2021-284) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa enacts a by-law repealing previous designations for St. Joseph Boulevard and Orléans Community Improvement Project Areas and establishing a new Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan Project Area encompassing the land outlined in Schedule A.

items.name: integrity-commissioner-law-no-2021-7.md
items.title: Integrity Commissioner (By-law No. 2021-7) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law establishing an Integrity Commissioner with defined responsibilities encompassing investigations, reporting, and independent oversight of the municipality, including roles as Lobbyist Registrar, Meetings Investigator, and with protections against liability for actions taken in good faith.

items.name: licensing-law-no-2002-189.md
items.title: Licensing (By-law No. 2002-189) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates business licenses within a city, consolidating numerous previous amendments. It defines key terms, outlines the process for obtaining and renewing licenses, establishes powers for enforcement, and details penalties for non-compliance.  It covers a wide range of businesses including entertainment venues, food establishments, retail shops, and transportation services, with specific provisions for adult entertainment and related activities. The by-law also establishes procedures for suspension and revocation of licenses, and includes sections on inspections, fees, and reporting requirements.

items.name: licensing-law-no-2002-189%2Fbusinesses-regulated-licensing-law-no-2002-189.md
items.title: Businesses Regulated by Licensing (By-law No. 2002-189) | City of Ottawa
items.summary:
This by-law regulates the operation of various businesses within the City, including:

*   **Auctioneers:** Requires a license, sets conditions for issuance (age, good character, compliance with zoning, prohibitions against misrepresentation), outlines responsibilities regarding record-keeping, and addresses transferability.

*   **Driving Schools:**  Establishes stringent licensing requirements for both operators and instructors, including vehicle standards, insurance, and documentation.

*   **Mobile Refreshment Vendors (including Pet Shops):**  Details licensing procedures, exemptions, conditions for renewal, and requirements for displaying information to customers.

*   **Payday Loan Establishments:**  Mandates a license, outlines conditions for issuance and renewal, specifies required information to be displayed, and includes indemnification clauses.

Essentially, this document provides the rules and regulations for these businesses to operate legally within the City.

items.name: light-rail-regulatory-monitor-and-compliance-officer-and-lrt-regulation-law-no-2015-301.md
items.title: Light Rail Regulatory Monitor and Compliance Officer and LRT Regulation (By-law No. 2015-301) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a framework for regulating the Confederation Line and other light rail transit systems within Ottawa, designating a Light Rail Regulatory Monitor and Compliance Officer to oversee safety, security, and operational standards. It outlines the officer’s duties, reporting requirements, and access to information, while also referencing relevant agreements and legislation to ensure compliance with federal and provincial regulations.

items.name: lobbyist-registry-law-no-2012-309.md
items.title: Lobbyist Registry (By-law No. 2012-309) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes the City of Ottawa’s Lobbyist Registry, outlining registration requirements, definitions of lobbying and related terms, exemptions, restrictions on lobbying activities, and the role of the Integrity Commissioner as Registrar. It details procedures for handling complaints, including investigation processes, potential sanctions, and reporting requirements to City Council, all while adhering to the Municipal Act and maintaining transparency and accountability.  The by-law also includes a Lobbyists’ Code of Conduct emphasizing honesty, openness, and avoiding conflicts of interest.

items.name: low-speed-vehicles-law-no-2022-276.md
items.title: Low-Speed Vehicles (By-law No. 2022-276) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Low-Speed Vehicles By-law regulates the operation and use of these vehicles within the city, adhering to Ontario Regulation 215/17 and the Highway Traffic Act, outlining specific requirements regarding speed limits, insurance, safety equipment, permits, and operational restrictions, with potential fines for non-compliance.

items.name: marijuana-grow-operation-remediation-law-no-2012-402.md
items.title: Marijuana Grow Operation Remediation (By-law No. 2012–402) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law, enacted by the City of Ottawa, establishes regulations concerning marijuana grow operations within the city. It outlines procedures for identifying, inspecting, and remediating properties used for such operations, placing responsibility for costs on property owners. Key provisions include definitions, prohibitions, inspection rights for officials, requirements for remediation, and penalties for non-compliance. The by-law also details processes for issuing orders, serving notices, and obtaining certificates of compliance, alongside fees associated with enforcement activities.

items.name: montreal-road-community-improvement-plan-area-law-no-2019-213.md
items.title: Montreal Road Community Improvement Plan Area (By-law No. 2019-213) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa enacts a by-law designating a specific area, as outlined in Schedule “A,” known as the Montreal Road Community Improvement Project Area, for the purpose of implementing a community improvement plan.

items.name: municipal-accommodation-tax-law-no-2022-56.md
items.title: Municipal Accommodation Tax (By-law No. 2022-56) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Municipal Accommodation Tax (MAT) by-law has been amended to increase the tax rate from four to five percent, effective January 1, 2024. Key changes include exemptions for certain entities (Crown, educational institutions, hospitals, etc.), adjustments to collection and remittance procedures, and penalties for non-compliance. The by-law also clarifies definitions related to transient accommodation and establishes a process for dispute resolution and enforcement.

items.name: noise-law-no-2017-255.md
items.title: Noise (By-law No. 2017-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for noise levels within the City, outlining prohibited activities like excessive shouting and loud machinery, setting decibel limits for various sources (vehicles, equipment, etc.), and detailing exemptions for specific events, construction, and agricultural operations, with associated fines and application procedures.

items.name: notices-and-other-communications-during-postal-service-interruption-law-no-2018-306.md
items.title: Notices and other communications during a postal service interruption (By-law No. 2018-306) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law authorizing the use of alternative methods, such as personal delivery, facsimile, and email, for delivering notices and communications when a postal service interruption occurs, with specific provisions for notices from the City and to the City, excluding those mandated by the Official Plan.

items.name: open-air-fire-law-no-2004-163.md
items.title: Open Air Fire (By-law No. 2004-163) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates open air fires within the City, outlining conditions for permits, prohibited areas, types of fires allowed, safety requirements, and enforcement measures. It details specific regulations for barbecues, brush fires, burn drums, windrows, and outdoor fireplaces, while also addressing exemptions for certain events and organizations. The by-law includes definitions of key terms, outlines permit application procedures, and establishes penalties for non-compliance, referencing previous municipal by-laws and incorporating amendments made over time.

items.name: ottawa-mural-law-no-2022-304.md
items.title: Ottawa Mural (By-law No. 2022-304) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the creation and maintenance of murals within the City, outlining permit requirements, content restrictions, and enforcement procedures. It defines key terms like “mural,” “City Sponsor,” and “alter,” establishes a Mural Review Panel for assessment, and details consequences for non-compliance, including fines and potential revocation of permits. The by-law also addresses exemptions for pre-existing murals and funding through City Sponsors, while emphasizing the importance of respecting heritage designations and maintaining mural quality.

items.name: over-dimensional-vehicles-city-highways-law-no-2003-497.md
items.title: Over-dimensional Vehicles on City Highways (By-law No. 2003-497) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for the movement of oversized vehicles within the City, outlining definitions, permit requirements, emergency procedures, and restrictions, particularly within the downtown core. It details various permit types (annual, project, single-trip), sets weight and dimension limits, mandates traffic management plans, and addresses issues like night movements and potential damage. The by-law also includes provisions for enforcement, penalties, and the repeal of previous municipal regulations, alongside fee schedules and a map designating the downtown core area subject to stricter rules.

items.name: parking-administrative-penalty-system-law-law-no-2025-156.md
items.title: Parking Administrative Penalty System By-law (By-law No. 2025-156) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a system for imposing administrative penalties and fees on traffic and parking violations within the City. It outlines the legal basis for the system, defines key terms, and details the process for issuing penalties, requesting reviews, and enforcing payment. The by-law specifies various contraventions, associated penalties, and late payment fees, as well as procedures for serving notices, conducting reviews, and handling non-payment. It also addresses the handling of screening and hearing officer reviews, including requirements for attendance and documentation. Finally, the by-law includes provisions for dealing with unsuccessful reviews and ensuring the City can pursue enforcement actions, such as plate denial.

items.name: parkland-dedication-law-no-2022-280.md
items.title: Parkland Dedication (By-law No. 2022-280) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law updates the City of Ottawa’s rules for parkland dedication during development and redevelopment. It repeals the previous Parkland Dedication By-law (2009-95) and establishes new requirements based on density, development type, and location.  The by-law outlines various methods for fulfilling parkland obligations – direct land conveyance, cash-in-lieu payments, or a combination of both.  It details specific rates for different development scenarios, including residential, commercial, and mixed-use projects, and establishes provisions for special areas like transit-oriented developments and Kanata, with potential exemptions and adjustments.  The by-law also clarifies the process for determining land values for cash-in-lieu payments and establishes a framework for administering and enforcing these requirements, including a system for handling disagreements and ensuring compliance.

items.name: parks-and-facilities-law-no-2025-251.md
items.title: Parks and Facilities (By-law No. 2025-251) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City’s Parks and Facilities By-law regulates park and facility use, outlining rules for behavior, vehicles, alcohol, wildlife, and more. It establishes general operating hours, prohibits reckless activities and littering, restricts motorized vehicles (except wheelchairs), and bans smoking and vaping. Specific regulations cover animal control, sports activities, alcohol consumption in designated areas, and the use of advertising devices. The by-law also details definitions of key terms, outlines enforcement procedures, and establishes penalties for violations. Amendments from 2004 to 2025 reflect ongoing adjustments to these regulations.

items.name: permanent-signs-private-property-law-no-2016-326.md
items.title: Permanent Signs on Private Property (By-law No. 2016-326) | City of Ottawa
items.summary:
This by-law regulates permanent signs on private property in the City, replacing an older bylaw. It outlines detailed rules regarding sign types, sizes, locations, illumination, and exemptions. Key aspects include:

*   **Scope:** It covers various sign types (billboards, banners, message centres, etc.) and applies to both private and City-owned property.
*   **Permitting:** All signs require permits, with specific procedures and fees.
*   **Lansdowne & Palladium Site:** Special regulations apply to these areas, prioritizing heritage and public space.
*   **Parliamentary Precinct/Confederation Boulevard/Rideau Canal:** Strict limitations on sign size and content to preserve the area’s historical significance.
*   **Enforcement:** Penalties for non-compliance and procedures for removal of unauthorized signs.
*   **Existing Signs:** Rules for existing signs and how they transition under the new bylaw.
*   **Fees:** Schedule A details the associated fees for permits and related services.

Essentially, the bylaw aims to balance the right to advertise with the need to maintain a visually appealing and historically significant cityscape.

items.name: pool-enclosure-law-no-2013-39.md
items.title: Pool Enclosure (By-law No. 2013-39) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the construction and maintenance of enclosures for privately-owned outdoor pools within the City, effectively replacing an older by-law. It establishes detailed requirements for enclosure design, materials, and safety features, including height, gate mechanisms, and access restrictions. The by-law outlines permit procedures, inspection processes, and penalties for non-compliance, with specific regulations for hot tubs and temporary enclosures. It also addresses enforcement actions and the continuation of existing permits. Finally, it establishes fees for permit applications.

items.name: private-approach-law-no-2003-447.md
items.title: Private Approach (By-law No. 2003-447) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law, enacted by the City of Ottawa, regulates private approaches to highways, outlining definitions, permitting processes, design standards, and enforcement measures. It addresses issues like access impact studies, culvert construction, parking regulations, and compliance with existing zoning and road activity by-laws. The by-law aims to maintain traffic flow, public safety, and the character of the city’s neighborhoods, particularly in mature areas, while accommodating farm and field access. It establishes procedures for obtaining permits, outlines responsibilities for maintenance, and details penalties for non-compliance, including potential remedial action and fees.

items.name: procedure-law-no-2025-100.md
items.title: Procedure (By-law No. 2025-100) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law governs the procedures for Ottawa City Council and its committees, outlining rules for meetings, debate, voting, and member conduct. It establishes a framework for decision-making, including provisions for suspending rules, handling public inquiries, and managing agenda items. Key elements include a system for expedited decision-making through a “consent agenda,” procedures for dealing with emergency situations, and guidelines for committee operations. The by-law also details the roles and responsibilities of the Mayor, committee chairs, and other council members, and establishes a process for nominating committee members.

items.name: procurement-law-no-2000-50.md
items.title: Procurement (By-law No. 2000-50) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes guidelines for the procurement of goods, services, and construction by the City, aiming for value and fairness in supplier relationships. It outlines detailed procedures, definitions, and responsibilities, including requirements for competitive bidding, contract awards, and supplier performance. The by-law also addresses specific considerations such as non-competitive purchases, standing offers, and legal aspects like contract amendments and litigation exclusions, all while adhering to relevant legislation and ensuring transparency and accountability.

items.name: property-maintenance-law-no-2005-208.md
items.title: Property Maintenance (By-law No. 2005-208) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Property Maintenance By-law, consolidated as of December 2019, regulates various aspects of property upkeep to ensure public safety and a clean environment, encompassing rules regarding snow and ice removal, drainage, storage of materials, waste disposal, landscaping, and the maintenance of buildings and surrounding lands. It establishes procedures for enforcement, including notices of violation and potential fines, and repeals previous municipal by-laws related to similar issues. The by-law also defines key terms and addresses specific considerations for naturalized gardens and boulevard maintenance.

items.name: property-standards-law-no-2013-416.md
items.title: Property Standards (By-law No. 2013-416) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document consolidates the City of Ottawa’s Property Standards By-law, incorporating amendments from 2017 to 2024. It establishes regulations for residential, non-residential, and vacant properties, addressing issues like waste management, building maintenance, safety standards, and heritage preservation. The by-law defines key terms, outlines enforcement procedures, and establishes a Property Standards and License Appeals Committee. It also includes sections on compliance reporting fees and a transition clause referencing previous property standards by-laws.

items.name: remembrance-day-law-no-2008-355.md
items.title: Remembrance Day (By-law No. 2008-355) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Remembrance Day By-law (No. 2008-355) mandates that most retail businesses remain closed until 12:30 pm on November 11th, with specific exemptions for certain establishments like food stores, pharmacies, bookstores, convenience stores, nurseries, gas stations, and vehicle-related businesses, provided they meet size criteria.  The by-law also applies to tourist areas and street vendors, while excluding hotels, restaurants, recreational facilities, and medical offices.  A retail business can be exempt if it solely sells foodstuffs, tobacco, antiques, or handicrafts, has limited staff (no more than three), and a total area of under 2,400 square feet, or if it’s a pharmacy selling only pharmaceutical goods, has an area under 7,500 square feet, or deals solely with fuel or nursery stock.  Violations result in fines, and the by-law is enforced by the Director of By-law and Regulatory Services, with a provision for prohibiting future offenses.  Finally, By-law No. 2002-421 is repealed, and the by-law is referred to as the “Remembrance Day By-law.”

items.name: rental-housing-property-management-law-no-2020-255.md
items.title: Rental Housing Property Management (By-law No. 2020-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for managing residential rental properties in Ottawa, outlining definitions of key terms like “apartment building,” “landlord,” and “tenant,” and detailing procedures for tenant service requests, capital maintenance plans for buildings, and pest management. It also addresses responsibilities for providing information to tenants, including details on emergency procedures and support registries, and outlines penalties for non-compliance. Finally, it exempts certain types of housing and establishes enforcement mechanisms through by-law officers.

items.name: residential-protective-plumbing-law-no-2025-89.md
items.title: Residential Protective Plumbing (By-law No. 2025-89) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa is establishing a by-law to provide rebates for residential properties installing protective plumbing devices – such as backwater valves and sump pumps – to mitigate basement flooding caused by sewer backups.  The by-law outlines eligibility criteria, application procedures, rebate amounts, and clarifies the City’s limited liability, effectively replacing an older by-law.

items.name: right-entry-law-no-2005-326.md
items.title: Right of Entry (By-law No. 2005-326) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Right of Entry By-law outlines the process for obtaining permission to enter an adjoining property for repairs or alterations to buildings, fences, or structures, requiring a permit application, fee payment, deposit, and adherence to specific conditions regarding restoration and notice to the property owner.

items.name: right-way-patio-law-no-2023-230.md
items.title: Right of Way Patio (By-law No. 2023-230) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the establishment and operation of Right of Way (ROW) patios on city highways in Ottawa, amending and repealing previous regulations. It defines key terms, outlines the application process, specifies requirements for design, safety, and operation (including restrictions on noise, smoking, and signage), and establishes procedures for approval, enforcement, and fee recovery. The by-law distinguishes between various patio types (cafe seating, front, curb-side, street-side, and parklets) and sets seasonal limitations and conditions for their use, with a focus on maintaining pedestrian access and public safety. It also details mechanisms for addressing non-compliance, including corrective work orders and potential cost recovery.

items.name: road-activity-law-no-2003-445.md
items.title: Road Activity (By-law No. 2003-445) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates road activity on City highways, establishing definitions, permitting procedures, and requirements for road cuts and temporary encroachments. It outlines fees, insurance stipulations, security deposits, and procedures for notifying the public and the City of planned work. Key elements include emergency work provisions, reinstatement standards, traffic control requirements, and penalties for non-compliance, with specific details on fees and security amounts based on the type and duration of the activity. The by-law also addresses responsibilities for repairs and indemnification, and clarifies procedures for temporary road closures and surface encroachment.

items.name: sewer-connection-law-no-2003-513.md
items.title: Sewer Connection (By-law No. 2003-513) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for sewer connections and sewage works within the City, defining key terms, outlining the City’s responsibilities, and detailing procedures for permits, inspections, maintenance, and addressing issues like blockages and tree root interference. It also includes charges for frontage and sewer capital improvements, and establishes a framework for addressing property owner responsibilities and City obligations related to sewer systems.

items.name: sewer-use-law-law-no-2025-94.md
items.title: Sewer Use By-law (By-law No. 2025–94) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates discharges to the City’s sewer system, outlining permitted and prohibited materials, monitoring requirements, and fees for industrial operations. It establishes procedures for obtaining sewer discharge permits, addresses specific waste streams like food waste and hazardous chemicals, and details penalties for non-compliance. The by-law also includes provisions for corrective action and outlines a framework for pollution prevention through compliance programs.

items.name: shopping-cart-law-no-2013-252.md
items.title: Shopping Cart (By-law No. 2013-252) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Shopping Cart By-law No. 2013-252 prohibits the use and placement of shopping carts on highways and City property, requiring businesses to implement a management system to prevent cart removal and ensuring carts are clearly marked.  If carts are left on public spaces, they will be impounded and subject to storage fees, with uncollected carts eventually disposed of after a specified period, accompanied by penalties for offenders.

items.name: short-term-borrowing-law-no-2019-268.md
items.title: Short Term Borrowing (By-law No. 2019-268) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s by-law authorizes temporary borrowing of funds to cover current expenditures, subject to limitations based on estimated revenues and time of year, and includes provisions for loan agreements, repayment schedules, and the repeal of previous borrowing authorizations.

items.name: short-term-rental-law-no-2021-104.md
items.title: Short-Term Rental (By-law No. 2021-104) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This consolidated by-law regulates short-term rentals within the City, outlining permitting requirements, guest limitations, marketing rules, insurance obligations, and enforcement procedures. It defines key terms, establishes a process for obtaining host permits, and addresses issues such as property standards, platform registration, and municipal accommodation tax collection. The by-law also includes provisions for prohibiting short-term rentals in certain properties and outlines penalties for non-compliance, with a focus on maintaining public health, safety, and minimizing nuisance impacts.

items.name: signs-city-roads-law-no-2003-520.md
items.title: Signs on City Roads (By-law No. 2003-520) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law, enacted in 2003 and updated in 2021, establishes regulations for signs and advertising devices on City roads. It defines various types of signs, prohibits their placement in specific locations (like roadways, sidewalks, and near intersections), outlines rules for temporary banners and election signs, and details procedures for obtaining permits and handling removed signs. The by-law also addresses conflicts with existing local by-laws and establishes penalties for non-compliance, aiming to maintain clear visibility and safety on City streets.

items.name: site-alteration-law-no-2024-448.md
items.title: Site Alteration (By-law No. 2024-448) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates site alterations within the City of Ottawa to protect agricultural resources, natural heritage features, and prevent drainage issues. It establishes exemptions for normal farm practices and outlines specific requirements for activities like Topsoil removal, construction near natural features, and ditch alterations. Key provisions include environmental impact studies for sensitive areas, restrictions on obstructing waterways, and procedures for obtaining approvals and addressing potential violations. The by-law also details definitions of relevant terms and establishes penalties for non-compliance, while acknowledging exceptions for City operations, approved developments, and certain infrastructure projects.

items.name: site-plan-control-law-no-2014-256.md
items.title: Site Plan Control (By-law No. 2014 - 256) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes Site Plan Control for the entire City of Ottawa, designating it as an area requiring approval for development. It outlines exemptions for certain developments, including residential buildings under specific conditions, some accessory structures, and temporary uses. The by-law defines key terms, establishes procedures for obtaining approvals, and details requirements for building elevations to ensure design consistency with the Official Plan. It also addresses lien provisions and provides an alternative to site plan control agreements through a letter of undertaking, and specifies conditions for exemptions related to rapid transit development and existing buildings.

items.name: small-business-tax-subclass-law-no-2021-343.md
items.title: Small Business Tax Subclass (By-law No. 2021-343) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a Small Business Tax Class within the City of Ottawa, governed by provincial assessment legislation. It defines key terms, outlines eligibility criteria for properties to be included in the subclass based on meeting specific criteria related to their use and size, and details the process for determining and maintaining inclusion, including an audit mechanism and a review process by an Appellate Authority. The by-law also establishes roles and responsibilities for program administration and appeals, and sets deadlines for these processes, concluding with a date of implementation and references to supporting schedules outlining property codes.

items.name: smoking-and-vaping-law-no-2019-241.md
items.title: Smoking and Vaping (By-law No. 2019-241) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law prohibiting smoking and vaping in designated public and workplace areas, including outdoor spaces, markets, and stadiums, while also regulating the presence of smoking paraphernalia like ashtrays and water pipes. The by-law outlines enforcement measures, repeals previous related legislation, and establishes specific definitions to clarify prohibited substances and locations.

items.name: solid-waste-services-law-no-2024-453.md
items.title: Solid Waste Services (By-law No. 2024 - 453) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document consolidates the City of Ottawa’s Property Standards By-law, outlining waste management regulations, including acceptable materials, collection schedules, fees, and enforcement procedures. It details eligibility for curbside services, defines various waste categories (garbage, recyclables, organic, bulky), specifies container requirements, and establishes rules for public space waste disposal. The by-law also addresses fees for trail waste facility services and outlines prohibited waste materials, emphasizing environmental protection and compliance.

items.name: special-events-city-streets-law-no-2001-260.md
items.title: Special Events on City Streets (By-law No. 2001-260) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Special Events By-law establishes a framework for permitting and regulating events held on public streets, outlining procedures for applications, insurance requirements, conditions of approval, and enforcement measures, including potential prohibitions and penalties for violations.

items.name: special-events-public-and-private-property-law-no-2013-232.md
items.title: Special Events on Public and Private Property (By-law No. 2013-232) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates special events held on public and private property in Ottawa, aiming to enhance the city’s quality of life, tourism, and economic development while ensuring public safety and minimizing disruption. It establishes a centralized “Event Central Office” to coordinate event planning, requires permits for all events exceeding a certain attendance, outlines specific requirements for applications (including plans, emergency procedures, and security), and details conditions for permit issuance related to services like medical, fire, and police support.  The by-law also establishes fees for city services and outlines procedures for appealing permit decisions and addresses enforcement measures.

items.name: temporary-signs-private-property-law-no-2004-239.md
items.title: Temporary Signs on Private Property (By-law No. 2004-239) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the placement of temporary signs on private property in the City of Ottawa. It outlines permitted sign types (like election and real estate signs), prohibited placements (near roadways, trees, etc.), permit requirements, and associated fees. Amendments from previous by-laws are included, and specific rules apply to inflatable signs and signs in Lansdowne Park. The by-law also details procedures for sign removal and addresses conflicts with existing local regulations. Contact information for inquiries and enforcement is provided.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301.md
items.title: Traffic and Parking (By-law No. 2017-301) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law outlines regulations for traffic and parking on roadways, including definitions, sign placement, parking rules on various properties, speed limits, traffic movement, pedestrian and bicycle considerations, penalties, and procedures for reporting parking violations, with specific details regarding accessible parking and enforcement.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301%2Fadministration.md
items.title: Administration | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes regulations for parking, traffic control, and accessibility within the city, defining key terms like accessible parking permits, accessible vehicles, authorized vehicles, bicycle parking, and various road designations (boulevard, median strip, etc.). It also outlines rules regarding traffic signals, signage, and specific vehicle types (school buses, taxicabs, etc.), along with provisions for transit, pedestrian access, and enforcement through municipal officers.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301%2Fpart-b-parking-private-property-and-city-property.md
items.title: Part B - Parking - Private property and city property | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Unauthorized parking on private and City property is prohibited, subject to specific regulations and consent requirements, including signage, designated parking areas, time limits, loading zones, and electric vehicle spaces. Violations result in fines and potential vehicle impoundment, with enforcement handled by designated officers and subject to established procedures.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301%2Fpart-c-parking-required-persons-disabilities.md
items.title: Part C - Parking required for persons with disabilities | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Obligated organizations must provide specific numbers of accessible parking spaces based on the size of their facility, adhering to minimum width requirements and incorporating access aisles with clear markings. These spaces must meet accessibility standards outlined in Ontario Regulation 191/11, including surface specifications, signage, and vertical clearance, while also ensuring unobstructed access and prohibiting unauthorized use through permit requirements and penalties for violations.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301%2Fpart-d-parking-municipal-parking-lots.md
items.title: Part D - Parking on municipal parking lots | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Parking on municipal lots is governed by rules regarding payment, space usage, obstruction, prohibited areas (like loading zones and reserved spaces), and equipment protection, with penalties for violations including fines and vehicle removal.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301%2Fpart-rules-road.md
items.title: Part A - Rules of the road | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates parking and traffic control on city highways, establishing rules for vehicle placement, signage, and driver behavior to ensure public safety and convenience. It details specific regulations for various situations, including designated zones for loading, bus stops, accessible parking, and special events, as well as prohibitions against obstructing traffic, racing, and improper vehicle operation. The by-law also outlines penalties for violations and clarifies the roles of enforcement officers and the application of the Highway Traffic Act.

items.name: transit-law-no-2007-268.md
items.title: Transit (By-law No. 2007-268) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates public transit operations within the City, outlining rules for vehicles, pedestrians, and fare payment. It establishes definitions for key terms, details procedures for yielding right-of-way, prohibits certain actions like blocking lanes and parking in prohibited areas, and addresses the operation of emergency vehicles and transit vehicles.  The by-law also specifies requirements for obtaining permits, managing service animals, and handling incidents involving transit vehicles.  Finally, it details regulations regarding signage, stopping distances, and the use of emergency signals, all with the goal of ensuring safe and orderly transit operations.

items.name: tree-protection-law-no-2020-340.md
items.title: Tree Protection (By-law No. 2020-340) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes a by-law to protect municipal and private trees within the City, aiming to maintain and grow the urban forest. It outlines detailed requirements for tree removal, including application processes, impact assessments, and replacement planting. The by-law specifies exemptions, defines key terms, and establishes procedures for enforcement, emphasizing the importance of retaining existing vegetation and incorporating it into development plans. It also details the information required for a Tree Conservation Report, including mapping, species inventories, and mitigation strategies. Finally, it establishes guidelines for tree planting and sets forth penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: use-and-care-roads-law-no-2003-498.md
items.title: Use and Care of Roads (By-law No. 2003-498) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law, enacted by the City of Ottawa, regulates the use and care of roads, defining key terms related to roadways, boulevards, and landscaping. It outlines prohibitions against various activities on highways, including dumping, obstructing drains, and damaging infrastructure.  The by-law also establishes requirements for boulevard gardens, including plant restrictions and maintenance, and addresses temporary retail displays and snow plow markings. Finally, it details exemptions and administrative procedures for enforcement and outlines the city’s authority to manage highway upkeep and address violations.

items.name: vacant-property-law-no-2022-197.md
items.title: Vacant Property (By-law No. 2022-197) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This consolidated by-law regulates vacant properties in the City, outlining permitting requirements, enforcement procedures, and exemptions. It establishes definitions related to vacant buildings and land, details permit conditions and renewal processes, and outlines responsibilities for property owners, including maintaining contact information and complying with building codes. The by-law also addresses signage, inspections, and penalties for non-compliance, with a focus on ensuring public safety and maintaining property standards.

items.name: vacant-unit-tax-law-no-2022-135.md
items.title: Vacant Unit Tax (By-law No. 2022-135) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law establishes a Vacant Unit Tax for the City of Ottawa, designed to address unoccupied residential properties. It outlines the legal basis for the tax, defines key terms, details the criteria for determining vacancy, sets the tax rate (which increases with consecutive years of vacancy), and establishes procedures for declaration, payment, audits, and appeals. The by-law also includes provisions for exemptions based on circumstances such as death, renovations, short-term rentals, and natural disasters, and addresses administrative matters like late declarations and penalties.

items.name: vehicle-hire-law-no-2016-272.md
items.title: Vehicle For Hire (By-law No. 2016-272) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Vehicle regulations for taxi and private transportation services in Ottawa are being updated to ensure accessibility and fair practices. These revisions include licensing requirements, driver qualifications, fare structures, and operational standards for both standard and accessible taxis, as well as private transportation companies. Key changes involve increased accessibility mandates, stricter driver background checks, enhanced monitoring of private transportation services through technology, and adjustments to licensing fees based on fleet size. The updated regulations also address issues like baggage fees, passenger rights, and driver responsibilities, while maintaining a focus on public safety and consumer protection.

items.name: voluntary-admail-reduction-program-law-no-2003-493.md
items.title: Voluntary Admail Reduction Program (By-law No. 2003-493) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa has enacted a by-law establishing a voluntary program to reduce unaddressed advertising material delivered to residents, requiring property owners to display a “no junk mail” sticker to prevent distributors from delivering material to their private property, with specific restrictions on distribution locations and times, excluding certain materials like newspapers and campaign literature.

items.name: ward-boundaries-and-council-composition-law-no-2021-3.md
items.title: Ward Boundaries and Council Composition (By-law No. 2021-3) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s ward boundaries and Council composition have been revised, with a new structure effective November 15, 2022, incorporating modifications approved by the Ontario Land Tribunal and subsequently amended by By-law 2025-5, which takes effect November 15, 2026.

items.name: ward-boundaries-wards-6-9-11-13-21-24-law-no-2025-5.md
items.title: Ward Boundaries of Wards 6, 9, 11, 13, 21, 24 (By-law No. 2025-5) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s by-law is amended to adjust the boundaries of Wards 6, 9, 11, 13, 21, and 24, incorporating redistributions of land as detailed in Schedules 1 through 3, effective November 15, 2026.

items.name: water-law-no-2025-227.md
items.title: Water (By-law No. 2025-227) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the city’s water supply, aiming for economic, social, and environmental well-being, public health, and consumer protection. It establishes detailed procedures for water service connections, maintenance, and backflow prevention, including definitions, permit requirements, fees, and responsibilities for property owners and the city. The by-law also outlines specific duties for city staff regarding water system operation, inspections, and enforcement, and addresses issues like water conservation and potential disruptions to service.

items.name: zoning-law-no-2008-250.md
items.title: Zoning (By-law No. 2008-250) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Zoning By-law, updated regularly through amendments, utilizes a complex system of zone codes, subzones, schedules, and exceptions to regulate land use. Minister’s Zoning Orders (MZO) supersede municipal by-laws, and property owners retain non-conforming rights for uses established under previous regulations.  The Consolidation provides access to these regulations, with Development Information Officers available for inquiries, and changes to the service are noted, emphasizing the importance of contacting them for specific property details and amendment information.

items.name: zoning-law-no-2008-250%2Fzoning-law-2008-250-consolidation.md
items.title: Zoning By-law 2008-250 Consolidation | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The City of Ottawa’s Zoning By-law, consolidated to June 18, 2025, outlines regulations for land use across the city, categorized into sections addressing administration, interpretation, definitions, general provisions, specific uses, parking, residential matters, various zones (residential, institutional, open space, industrial, transportation, and rural), and supplementary details like appendices, schedules, and zoning maps. It provides guidance on permitted uses, setbacks, building heights, and other development standards, with a process for seeking clarification from Development Information Officers and the Committee of Adjustment. The by-law also incorporates Section 37 provisions related to urban and rural exceptions and amendments.

items.name: zoning-law-no-2008-250%2Fzoning-law-2008-250-consolidation%2Fpart-15-exceptions.md
items.title: Part 15 - Exceptions | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The document details a comprehensive list of exceptions to standard zoning provisions, organized into numbered and lettered ranges, and specifies a point of contact for verification.

items.name: zoning-law-no-2008-250%2Fzoning-law-2008-250-consolidation%2Fpart-17-schedules.md
items.title: Part 17 - Schedules | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines the City of Ottawa’s Zoning By-law, presenting a comprehensive collection of “Schedules” that provide specific zoning regulations for various areas and situations within the city. These schedules, identified by “SCH” followed by a number, detail rules regarding building heights, parking requirements, permitted uses, and other zoning considerations, with some schedules designated as “r” for rural applications. The document includes a large number of schedules, many of which are numbered consecutively from 1 to 198 and beyond, with numerous reserved entries for future use.
